basics.name: Mao Li
basics.label: PhD Candidate in Survey and Data Science
basics.summary: Expert in applying Large Language Models to social textual data, focusing on knowledge distilling and public opinion analysis. Specialized in computational social science with experience in interdisciplinary research collaborations.

education.institution: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
education.area: Survey and Data Science, Scientific Computing

education.institution: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI

work.name: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan
work.summary: Leading research on social media analysis for Census Bureau data enhancement, focusing on text summarization and stance detection.
highlights: Developed Twitter browser tool as a digital focus group for public opinion analysis
Implemented Parameter-efficient Fine-tuning methods to detect opinion stances in social media

work.name: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan
work.summary: Supported the National Neighborhood Data Archive project by creating neighborhood-level data and analyzing cognitive health data for aging Americans.
highlights: Integrated neighborhood data at multiple spatial levels
Contributed to NIH-funded research on cognitive resilience in aging

projects.name: Twitter Browser Tool
projects.summary: In-progress web application that provides a user-friendly interface for advanced Twitter data summarization, allowing non-technical users to gain insights from social media data.
highlights: Improved user experience by transforming complex Twitter data into concise insights

publications.name: Tracking Census Online Self-Completion Using Twitter Posts
publications.summary: Analyzes Census data engagement through Twitter, providing insights into online self-completion behaviors.

publications.name: Neighborhood Active Aging Infrastructure and Cognitive Health
publications.summary: Study on the impact of neighborhood infrastructure on cognitive health among aging Americans.

publications.name: Can Neighborhood Social Infrastructure Modify Cognitive Function?
publications.summary: Explores the relationship between neighborhood social infrastructure and cognitive function.
